title: 112_hr3030
content: The "Housing Opportunities Made Equal Act of 2011" or the "HOME Act of 2011" amends the Fair Housing Act to prohibit certain discrimination. The "HOME Act of 2011" amends the Fair Housing Act to include protections for actual or perceived race, color, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, and source of income. The Fair Housing Act and Civil Rights Act are amended to include protections for actual or perceived race, color, sexual orientation, gender identity, marital status, and source of income. The Fair Housing Act and Civil Rights Act are amended to include protections for gender identity, marital status, sexual orientation, and source of income. Gender identity refers to an individual's gender-related characteristics regardless of their designated sex at birth. Marital status is defined as per the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. Sexual orientation includes homosexuality, heterosexuality, and bisexuality. Source of income encompasses public assistance and housing subsidies. SEC. 3 amends the Fair Housing Act to broaden the definition of discriminatory housing practices. It includes acts unlawful under specific sections and failure to comply with certain regulations. SEC. 4 amends the Act's definition of "familial status." SEC. 4 amends the Fair Housing Act definition of "familial status" to include individuals under 18 years residing with a parent, foster parent, or legal guardian. It also extends protections to pregnant individuals and those seeking legal custody of minors. The Equal Credit Opportunity Act is amended to grant the Attorney General pre-litigation subpoena power for investigations, allowing the issuance of civil investigative demands before initiating a civil action. This power mirrors that of the Attorney General under a specific section of the United States Code, with exceptions for qui tam relators. The Fair Housing Act is amended to allow the Attorney General to issue civil investigative demands before starting a civil proceeding if there is reason to believe someone has relevant information. The Attorney General can issue civil investigative demands under the Fair Housing Act, with authority similar to section 3733 of title 31, United States Code, excluding provisions related to qui tam relators. SEC. 6. FREEDOM FROM DISCRIMINATION IN CREDIT. The Equal Credit Opportunity Act is amended to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity. The definition of "gender identity" is clarified as gender-related characteristics regardless of designated sex at birth. The Equal Credit Opportunity Act is amended to include protection against discrimination based on sexual orientation, defined as homosexuality, heterosexuality, or bisexuality. The Fair Housing Act is amended to include discrimination in real estate transactions for failing to provide reasonable accommodations for people with disabilities. Additionally, changes are made to limitations on filing complaints and starting civil actions under the Act. The Fair Housing Act is amended to address the failure to design and construct dwellings in compliance with specific requirements.
